item.title: Israeli military pulls troops from southern Gaza
item.dc:creator: Yuliya Talmazan and Reuters and Yael Factor
item.description: The Israeli military says it has reduced the number of ground troops in the southern Gaza Strip following the conclusion of its monthslong operation in the city of Khan Younis, raising questions about the future of its offensive in the enclave amid pressure from the U.S. to reduce the war’s humanitarian toll.

media:content.media:text: An Israeli soldier moves atop a tank near the Israeli-Gaza border
media:content.media:description: An Israeli soldier moves atop a tank near the Israeli-Gaza border on April 4, 2024.

item.title: Video shows moments aid workers killed in Gaza are identified
item.description: Video shows the moments a World Central Kitchen aid worker identified his colleagues that were killed in an Israeli airstrike moments after the attack on the Gaza strip.

media:content.media:title: Video shows moments aid workers killed in Gaza are identified
media:content.media:description: Video shows the moments a World Central Kitchen aid worker identified his colleagues that were killed in an Israeli airstrike moments after the attack on the Gaza strip.

item.title: Aid agencies say the Israeli military has been attacking their workers for months
item.dc:creator: Gabe Joselow and Aurora Almendral and Doha Madani and Dan De Luce and Caroline Radnofsky and Matthew Mulligan
item.description: 224 aid workers have been killed since the start of the war, as the death of WCK aid workers highlight the failure of the Israeli military to protect aid workers in line with international humanitarian law.

media:content.media:text: A man displays blood-stained British, Polish, and Australian passports after an Israeli airstrike in Deir al-Balah, Gaza, on April 1, 2024, killed seven World Central Kitchen workers.
media:content.media:description: A man displays blood-stained British, Polish, and Australian passports after an Israeli airstrike in Deir al-Balah, Gaza, on April 1, 2024, killed seven World Central Kitchen workers.

media:content.media:text: Palestinians walking in front of the closed headquarters of the World Central Kitchen on April 3, 2024, west of Nuseirat, central Gaza.
media:content.media:description: Two women walk past the closed headquarters of the World Central Kitchen in central Gaza.

media:content.media:text: Palestinians look a vehicle in Deir Al-Balah, Gaza, on April 2, 2024, the day after it was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike that killed World Central Kitchen workers.
media:content.media:description: Palestinians look at a vehicle Monday in Deir Al-Balah, Gaza, the day after it was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike that killed World Central Kitchen workers.

item.title: Class destroyed: A look at what has become of Gaza's revered universities
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and Yasmine Salam and Matthew Mulligan and Bianca Britton
item.description: Built over decades, Gaza’s universities embodied the ambitions of young Palestinians. In weeks, the Israeli military destroyed them.

item.title: The Electoral College question looming over 2024
item.dc:creator: Mark Murray
item.description: The 2024 results may depend on whether Trump and Republicans have maintained the Electoral College advantage they held in the last two presidential elections.

media:content.media:text: Former President Donald Trump and President Joe Biden.
media:content.media:description: Former President Donald Trump and President Joe Biden.

item.title: GOP Rep. Mike Turner: Russian propaganda is 'being uttered on the House floor'
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Marquez
item.description: GOP Rep. Mike Turner on Sunday said that Russian propaganda has taken hold among some of his House Republican colleagues and is even "being uttered on the House floor."

media:content.media:text: Rep. Mike Turner at the Capitol
media:content.media:description: Rep. Mike Turner, R-Ohio, at the Capitol on January 9.

item.title: How immigrants are helping boost the U.S. job market without affecting inflation
item.dc:creator: Rob Wile
item.description: Blockbuster jobs growth continues to power the U.S. economy, with the BLS reporting 303,000 payrolls added in March. Immigrants are a big part of that success.

media:content.media:text: A bicycle delivery person crosses 42nd Street as the sun sets on May 29, 2023, in New York City.
media:content.media:description: A bicycle delivery person crosses 42nd Street as the sun sets in New York City in 2023.

item.title: Behind the movement that brought homosexuality — and psychiatry’s power — to a vote 50 years ago
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Ryan
item.description: Fifty years ago, the nation’s psychiatrists effectively put gay people’s mental health — and their very place in society — to a vote.

media:content.media:text: Demonstrators gathered in Albany, N.Y., in 1971 to demand gay rights and declare "Homo Is Healthy."
media:content.media:description: Demonstrators gathered in Albany, N.Y., in 1971 to demand gay rights and declare “Homo Is Healthy.”

media:content.media:text: Many outlets covered the APA’s decision to remove homosexuality from its list of mental disorders.
media:content.media:description: Many outlets covered the APA’s decision to remove homosexuality from its list of mental disorders.

media:content.media:text: "In the Shadow of Diagnosis" book cover.
media:content.media:description: "In the Shadow of Diagnosis" book cover.

media:content.media:description: Gay rights activist Frank Kameny, second in line, protests with others outside the White House on Armed Forces Day on May 15, 1965.

item.title: How a network of abortion pill providers works together in the wake of new threats
item.dc:creator: Abigail Brooks and Dasha Burns
item.description: As the Supreme Court decides whether to allow access restrictions to the abortion drug mifepristone, a network of providers is working to help women in states with bans.

media:content.media:text: abortion medicine
media:content.media:description: A shield law provider packs abortion pills into envelopes to be sent from New York to states with bans.

media:content.media:text: abortion pills tablets bottles
media:content.media:description: Bottles of Misoprostol Tablets.

media:content.media:description: Boxes of pills will be packed into envelopes to ship around the country.

media:content.media:description: Empty pill bottles in the basement of a shield law provider in New York will be filled with abortion medication.

item.title: How to best photograph the total solar eclipse on your phone
item.dc:creator: Chelsea Stahl and Mirna Alsharif
item.description: A total solar eclipse will cross North America Monday and eclipse mania has seized the U.S., with concerts, viewing parties and even a mass wedding planned along the path of totality to witness the once-in-a-generation celestial event.

media:content.media:text: A phone wearing eclipse ISO glasses.

item.title: UFC champ Jon Jones accused of threatening to kill woman collecting his urine for drug test
item.dc:creator: Dennis Romero and Rudy Chinchilla
item.description: UFC heavyweight champion Jon Jones was arrested Saturday based on allegations that he assaulted and threatened to kill a drug testing agent, police in New Mexico said.

media:content.media:text: Jon Jones meets with the media following his win over Cyril Gane at UFC 285 on March 5, 2023
media:content.media:description: Jon Jones meets with the media following his win over Cyril Gane at UFC 285 on March 5, 2023.

item.title: $1.3 billion Powerball winning ticket sold in Oregon after draw delays
item.dc:creator: Rudy Chinchilla and Yuliya Talmazan
item.description: A lucky player from Oregon has scooped up the $1.3 billion Powerball jackpot on Saturday after the highly anticipated drawing was delayed over what the Multi-State Lottery Association said was one lottery’s need for additional time to complete security procedures.

media:content.media:text: Powerball tickets are shown in front of a screen displaying the estimated jackpot
media:content.media:description: Powerball tickets are shown in front of a screen displaying the estimated jackpot on Wednesday, April 3, 2024, in Surfside, Fla. The Powerball has grown to an estimated $1.3 billion ahead of the drawing on April 6, 2024,

item.title: Stolen son: A hostage’s mom fights to bring her child home from Gaza
item.description: Rachel Goldberg-Polin's son, 23-year-old Hersh Goldberg-Polin, was taken by Hamas on Oct. 7, 2023. In the six months since, she has become a vocal advocate in the effort to free the over 100 hostages that remain in Gaza — all while bearing the daily burden of pretending to be normal.

media:content.media:title: Stolen son: A hostage’s mom fights to bring her child home from Gaza
media:content.media:description: Rachel Goldberg-Polin's son, 23-year-old Hersh Goldberg-Polin, was taken by Hamas on Oct. 7, 2023. In the six months since, she has become a vocal advocate in the effort to free the over 100 hostages that remain in Gaza — all while bearing the daily burden of pretending to be normal.

item.title: Kentucky man admits to faking his own death to avoid paying over $100k in child support
item.dc:creator: Mirna Alsharif
item.description: A Kentucky man admitted to faking his own death to avoid paying over $100,000 in outstanding child support to his ex-wife, according to a plea agreement filed in U.S.

item.title: Iranian official warns Israel that its embassies are not safe after deadly Damascus strike
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: JERUSALEM — A top Iranian military adviser on Sunday warned Israel that none of its embassies were safe following a strike in Damascus last week blamed on Israel that killed 12 people, including two elite Iranian generals.

media:content.media:text: Emergency services work at a destroyed building hit by an Israeli air strike
media:content.media:description: Emergency services work at a destroyed building from the consular section of Iran's embassy, hit by an Israeli air strike, in Damascus, Syria, on Monday.

media:content.media:description: Children stand on a rooftop overlooking the destruction in Rafah, Gaza, on Tuesday, following overnight Israeli bombardment.

media:content.media:text: Food distribution in Gaza amid Israeli attacks
media:content.media:description: Palestinian children wait to receive food distributed by charity organizations in Deir Al Balah, Gaza, on Monday.

item.title: Trump tells billionaires he’ll keep their taxes low at $50 million fundraising gala
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Allen and Matt Dixon and Garrett Haake
item.description: WASHINGTON — Former President Donald Trump emphasized the importance of extending his signature tax cuts to some of the nation’s wealthiest political donors, according to a readout of his private remarks Saturday night provided by a Trump campaign official.

media:content.media:text: Donald Trump pumps his fist as he arrives for a GOP fundraiser
media:content.media:description: Donald Trump arrives for a GOP fundraiser in Palm Beach, Fla., on Saturday.

item.description: A solar eclipse will grace the skies over North America on Monday. Learn more about what times it's visible, how to watch and where the path of totality goes.

item.title: China says it patrolled the South China Sea in an apparent response to U.S. naval drills with allies
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: China’s military said Sunday that it had conducted air and sea patrols and that all activities that “disrupt the South China Sea” are under control, an apparent response to naval exercises by the U.S. and its allies.

item.title: Pellegrini wins Slovak presidential election in boost for pro-Russian prime minister
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Slovak nationalist-left government candidate Peter Pellegrini won the country’s presidential election on Saturday, cementing the grip of pro-Russian Prime Minister Robert Fico over the country.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: Slovakia's president-elect Peter Pellegrini.
